https://prez.dev/description.@value:
Listing of rock types and lithological nomenclature (and related codes) used by the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) for the dual purpose of recording lithologies during mapping / core logging, and for representing mappable lithostratigraphic/lithotectonic units in the State. Rather than attempting to cover for all existing rock types and lithologies, the GSWA’s scheme and terms in this vocabulary are specifically informed by Western Australian geology; a companion vocabulary covers lithological equivalents for regolith materials. 

Apart from the approach to classification of some volcanic (pyroclastic) rocks, GSWA's lithological nomenclature largely conforms to internationally recognized classifications such as Le Maitre et al. (2005) for plutonic/intrusive rocks and Fettes and Desmons (2007) for metamorphic rocks. Note that: a) GSWA prefers the term intrusive to plutonic, as it carries no inference on depth of emplacement; b) GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or sub-volcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks; c) some intrusive mafic/ultramafic terminology is allowed for cumulate rocks originating from thick volcanic successions. In the absence of a single unified scheme for sedimentary rocks, multiple sources were considered, and definitions rely heavily on the Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). Full references listed under History Note.

GSWA’s rock classification scheme is designed to provide consistent terminology within the organization, and primarily relies on features observable in all rocks at outcrop scale, in hand specimen, and in thin section. Additional terms cover for broader combinations of multiple lithologies encountered during mapping (especially for sedimentary rocks, e.g. ‘siliciclastic + lesser carbonate’), and to ensure a coherent approach across different rock types (e.g. use of ‘mylonitized’ for all metamorphic rock groups, even if some would be rare occurrences or difficult to identify in the field). Definitions in this vocabulary are largely compiled or derived from the quoted references and the Glossary of Geology (5th edition, revised, Neuendorf et al., 2011), with adaptions based on recommended GSWA usage; metamorphic lithologies are often derived from definitions of non-metamorphosed equivalents. Some mineralogical/petrological knowledge is expected of the reader.
 Each concept is characterized by a notation consisting of one to four lower-case letters. This notation represents the lithological code used for mapping lithologies and labelling lithostratigraphic units on maps. Note that in the GSWA's scheme, some lithological codes are reserved for use in the Field Observation database (WAROX) or the Explanatory Notes System (ENS) only; the latter are highlighted in the concept definitions and should not be used for field observations. Also note that in ENS codes are supplemented by primary and secondary qualifiers (not covered in this vocabulary); a concerted effort has been made to match WAROX-only codes with those generated via qualifiers in ENS, but in a few instances alphabetical limitations have prevented this (i.e. the code used in WAROX has a slightly different meaning from the same string of letters generated in ENS).

The approach behind GSWA’s rock classification scheme is documented in Tyler at al. (2004; https://dmpbookshop.eruditetechnologies.com.au/product/the-revised-gswa-rock-classification-scheme.do). Details of GSWA’s code construction for ENS can be found in Riganti et al. (2013; https://dmpbookshop.eruditetechnologies.com.au/product/gswa-code-builder-constructing-and-unravelling-gswa-geological-codes.do) and in a companion application, the GSWA Code Builder (ENS codes only), available from the Department’s Data and Software Centre (https://dasc.demirs.wa.gov.au/).

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of amphiboles. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

Fault rock that is cohesive and characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size for more than 90% of the rock volume, and displays a significant degree of grain growth related to or following deformation. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 134).

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of carbonate mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A cohesive fault rock with a poorly developed or absent schistosity, characterized by generally angular porphyroclasts and lithic fragments in a finer-grained matrix of similar composition that constitutes between 50 and 90% of the rock volume. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 138).

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of chlorite minerals. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A cohesive fault breccia formed by deformation that caused the fragmentation of the rock in place or nearly in place. In the classification of Fossen (2016) crush breccia specifically refers to occurrences where fragments are larger than 5 mm; GSWA usage of the term is for rocks of unknown protolith, and includes 'fine crush breccia' (fragments between 1 and 5 mm) and 'crush microbreccia' (fragments less than 1 mm). Crush breccias have less than 10% matrix and fragments are usually glued together by cement (typically quartz or calcite) and/or microfragments of minerals that have been crushed during faulting. Adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 143).

A fault rock in which the rock mass consists of greater than 30% visible, angular rock fragments resulting from fracturing and frictional slip along a fault; may be cohesive or incohesive. Adapted from Fossen (2016) and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

An incohesive fault rock with a high matrix–fragment ratio (visible fragments less than 30% of the rock mass), i.e. a strongly ground down version of the original rock. The term is sometimes also used for strongly reworked clay or shale in the core of faults in sedimentary sequences. Adapted from Fossen (2016). In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

Rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone, i.e. a zone of sheared, crushed or foliated rock, in which numerous small dislocations have occurred, adding up to an appreciable total offset of the undeformed walls. All gradations may occur, from multiple fault planes to single shear zones. (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 151)

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of feldspar mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished a red or rusty colour due to the presence of ferric oxides. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

An incohesive fault rock with a high matrix–fragment ratio (visible fragments less than 30% of the rock mass), i.e. a strongly ground down version of the original rock, with a distinct planar anisotropy (i.e. foliation). The term is sometimes also used for strongly reworked clay or shale in the core of faults in sedimentary sequences. Adapted from Fossen (2016). In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the presence of graphite/carbon. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A group name for lithologies physically associated with fault surfaces and genetically linked to fault movements (Glossary of geology, 5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Based on the Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al. 2011).

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A group name for lithologies physically associated with fault surfaces and genetically linked to fault movements (Glossary of geology, 5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of micaceous mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.
A fault that developed in a migmatite, under migmatitic conditions. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

Fault rock that is cohesive and characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size for 50–90% of the rock volume, and commonly containing rounded porphyroclasts and lithic fragments of similar composition to minerals in the matrix. Fine-scale layering and an associated mineral or stretching lineation are commonly present. Brittle deformation of some minerals may be present, but deformation is commonly by crystal plasticity. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 177).
Phyllosilicate-rich mylonite that has the lustrous sheen of a phyllite (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 183).

A cohesive fault rock with a poorly developed or absent schistosity, characterized by generally angular porphyroclasts and lithic fragments in a finer-grained matrix of similar composition that constitutes between 10 and 50% of the rock volume. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 188).

A mylonite in which less than 50% of the rock volume has undergone grain-size reduction (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 188); a mylonite with 10–50% matrix and 50–90% porphyroclasts (Passchier and Trouw, 2005).

Extremely fine-grained to glassy, dark, cohesive rock occurring as veins or as a matrix to pseudo-conglomerates or breccias, formed through frictional melting and subsequent quenching during earthquakes and large-scale landslides (Trouw et al., 2010). Note the vocabulary has a separate concept for pseudotachylite formed through impact events.

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of pyroxenes. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of quartz and feldspar mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of quartz. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.
A fault rock that retains some fissility. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A cohesive fault rock with a poorly developed or absent schistosity, characterized by generally angular porphyroclasts and lithic fragments in a finer-grained matrix of similar composition that constitutes more than 90% of the rock volume. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 202).

Mylonite in which more than 90% of the rock volume has undergone grain-size reduction (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p.  202); a mylonite with over 90% matrix and less than 10% porphyroclasts (Passchier and Trouw, 2005).
